review.title: Annotating Character Relationships in Literary Texts
review.abstract: We present a dataset of manually annotated relationships between characters in literary texts, in order to support the training and evaluation of automatic methods for relation type prediction in this domain (Makazhanov et al., 2014; Kokkinakis, 2013) and the broader computational analysis of literary character (Elson et al., 2010; Bamman et al., 2014; Vala et al., 2015; Flekova and Gurevych, 2015). In this work, we solicit annotations from workers on Amazon Mechanical Turk for 109 texts ranging from Homer's _Iliad_ to Joyce's _Ulysses_ on four dimensions of interest: for a given pair of characters, we collect judgments as to the coarse-grained category (professional, social, familial), fine-grained category (friend, lover, parent, rival, employer), and affinity (positive, negative, neutral) that describes their primary relationship in a text. We do not assume that this relationship is static; we also collect judgments as to whether it changes at any point in the course of the text.

sections.heading: 1 Overview
sections.text: We present a dataset of manually annotated relationships between characters in literary texts to support the training and evaluation of automatic methods for predicting relationship types in this area (Makazhanov et al., 2014; Kokkinakis, 2013) and to support the broader computational analysis of literary characters (Elson et al., 2010; Bamman et al., 2014; Vala et al., 2015; Flekova and Gurevych, 2015). In this work, we collect comments from workers on Amazon Mechanical Turk on four dimensions of interest: for a given pair of characters, we collect judgments regarding the coarse category (professional, social, familial), fine-grained category (friend, lover, parent, rival, employer) and affinity (positive, negative, neutral) that describes their primary relationship to a text.

sections.heading: 4 Data
sections.text: All comments are freely available at http: / / github.com / dbamman / characterRelations. Instead of resolving disagreements between commenters or filtering out incomplete answers, we provide all the information we collect; each comment is paired with an (anonymized) identifier of the commenter who provided it.
